headline: Pro-Bernie group endorses in key Dem Senate primary
sentences:
Asked for comment for this story, Barnes spokesperson Madeline McDaniel said, Mandela is proud to be endorsed by more than 130 local elected officials in Wisconsin, influential local and national groups, and members of Congress from all corners of the Democratic Party, from Sen. Elizabeth Warren and Sen. Cory Booker to [House] Majority Whip Jim Clyburn.?
Barnes has also received the support of liberal groups such as the Working Families Party, Progressive Change Campaign Committee and the Center for Popular Democracy Action.

Before it is lifted, he said we need to have a plan in place to make sure we're keeping asylum seekers and people in the U.S. safe.?
Barnes has also distanced himself from left-wing slogans to abolish ICE? and defund the police,? despite appearing open to them in the past.

The endorsement from Our Wisconsin Revolution, which was first shared with POLITICO, gives a much-needed adrenaline shot to Nelson's campaign and could help validate his claim that he is the true progressive in the race.

He must balance the need to win over liberal voters in the primary while preparing for a general election in a swing state against Republican Sen. Ron Johnson, in what is expected to be a challenging year for Democrats.

| Scott Olson/Getty Images
By Holly Otterbein
 04/28/2022 04:30 AM EDT
A Bernie Sanders-aligned group is throwing its weight behind underdog Tom Nelson in Wisconsin's closely watched Democratic Senate primary.

Mandela Barnes, the Democratic frontrunner who is also running as a liberal, faces dissatisfaction from some progressive activists as he distances himself from the far left in advance of the general election.
Barnes recently broke with President Joe Biden on immigration policy, saying that he disagreed with the administration's plan to end the pandemic-era border restriction known as Title 42.

He believes in the Green New Deal.?
Walton said that Barnes did not fill out a questionnaire from his group, and that made him ineligible for the endorsement.
Nelson, the Outagamie County executive, received the support of nearly 78 percent of voting members of Our Wisconsin Revolution in a ranked-choice process.
Barnes recently launched on an agriculture tour of Wisconsin, where he talked about policies to help farmers and forgotten? communities in rural areas.
I have consistently championed economic, social and racial justice issues, so voters know exactly where I stand, unlike others in the race,? he said.
Nineteen percent backed Barnes, while Milwaukee Bucks executive Alex Lasry received 16 percent and state treasurer Sarah Godlewski won 7 percent.
Mandela Barnes speaks at a rally for Wisconsin Democrats at North Division High School on October 26, 2018 in Milwaukee, Wisconsin.
Sunrise Wisconsin, a left-wing organization of young people aiming to stop climate change, endorsed Nelson over Barnes as well.
He has a strong stance on Medicare for All,? said Andre Walton, executive director of Our Wisconsin Revolution, of Nelson.
And while Barnes backs Medicare for All and the Green New Deal, he has not made them the central focus of his campaign.
In a Marquette Law School survey released this week, only 5 percent of likely voters said they were supporting Nelson.
Throughout the Senate campaign, Nelson has highlighted the fact that he was formerly a Sanders presidential delegate.
The snub of Barnes by Our Wisconsin Revolution underscores the tricky situation the lieutenant governor faces.

I'm the only one who opposes Title 42.?
Nelson faces an uphill climb to the nomination.
He has struggled with fundraising and has remained stuck in the single digits in polls.
Sanders founded Our Revolution after his 2016 presidential run.
His political fortunes depend on Barnes taking a nosedive.
